experience: You and Richard both know Alan Lobock, Justin Williams, and 12 others
Richard can introduce you to 4 people at Edgenuity Inc.

I work on a project called Axiom, which is a full technology pivot of their current software. I work in an ASP MVC stack connected to a MSSQL database. I was hired to help accelerate development and to bring my industry experience to the Axiom team.  The work always keeps me on my toes and has been a great opportunity to not only share what I know, but to learn a lot as well.

After my success helping to build the Modulus platform (and a few celebratory vacations), I took time to chase my own venture. My fascination with Youtube and Twitch led me to assemble a crew to try our hand at content production. My time in the online media scene taught me many things about production, audiences, live streaming, and the like. I also discovered what aspects of business I can cover, and some I am not really suited for. It was a great journey in my life, but for now I keep Loot Storm around mostly as a face for any consulting work I do in my free time.

My responsibilities with Paranoid Ferret started with small web development projects. After some time, I was offered a small percentage of the company in exchange for my help. This opportunity really introduced me to real-world examples of web development and help me grow my skills as an engineer, as well as a giving me a "crash course" in the basics of how software consulting really works.Some projects I am particularly proud of:► Co-created of a complete HTML5 JavaScript graphics engine► Wrote many programming tutorials, spanning many different languages and subjects► Co-created a real-time Tic Tac Toe facebook game utilizing Node.js

After Modulus was acquired by Progress Software I seized the opportunity to move into a training-based role. I used my technical knowledge to train current and future customers through workshops, conferences, and online programs. The curriculum I developed focused on utilizing Javascript, both client and server side, to build performant web applications. This helped bring customers to the platform while allowing me to travel and share my passion for development with others.► Generated new revenue by developing and delivering successful developer workshops► Created a new Customer Support Center to provide improved documentation and an enhanced support desk► Co-created a six-city tour to bring Node.js education to our major developer markets

In 2012 I was given the opportunity to help build a hosting platform for the then-young technology of Node.js. With the backing of  two other extremely talented developers, I seized the opportunity and moved back to my hometown of Cincinnati. This was necessary as the team was accepted into an accelerator program called The Brandery. My first responsibility was building the front-end, customer-facing web portal. However, being a part of a small startup means I touched pretty much every piece of the Modulus infrastructure. Not only did I accelerate my web development experience and knowledge by 10 fold, but I was mentored by some of the best minds in the entrepreneurship world during this time. This taught me invaluable lessons in business, marketing, and even a little financing. It was a lot of long nights and endless networking, but I would not trade those years for anything.

February 3, 2011, Brian and Richard were students together

I was Richard's roommate all throughout his time as an on campus student at UAT. Richard is not only a great person to know, but he is a hard worker and diligent programmer who is not afraid to pick up a new framework or API at a moment's notice and do something interesting with it.Richard is pretty much the ideal "team player." There is nobody he can't get along with. He's always focused on the project at hand and will do everything in his power to make sure it succeeds, even if it means putting in extra time or effort. Unless you need someone who is egotistical and controlling, I can't ever see a situation where Richard isn't the man for the job.

Brian and I were roommates for almost two and a half years, and say with much passion that Brian is not only a good person, but an excellent programmer. Anything from Scheme to C#, Brian knows what and how to do just about anything, and if he doesn't, he will learn very fast. If you have question about data structures, language syntax, or even code design, you can always count on Brian to give me the right answer in an understandable way.

summary: <body>Software is in my blood. Since my father helped me write my first program when I was 12, I was hooked.  I have worked in PHP, ASP, C#, and many other languages. I love learning and trying new things, so I tend to branch out to new ones from time to time. Over the years I found my real passion lies in web development. Front-end development to be exact. To go from a blank canvas to a web page that the world can enjoy always makes me proud. I have experience with full-stack work, but I usually just do what needs to be done to get things running. I really prefer the comfort of my HTML/CSS/JS. I also co-organize TucsonJS, which has been fun. Currently open to employment and consulting.</body>
name: Richard Key
